title-group.article-title: What is the Association Between Nontobacco Nicotine Dependence and Postoperative Complications in Total Hip Arthroplasty? A Large Propensity-Matched Cohort Study

contrib-group.aff: aDepartment of Orthopaedic Surgery, University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Cleveland, OH, USA
bDepartment of Orthopaedics, The MetroHealth System, Cleveland, OH, USA
cDepartment of Orthopaedic Surgery, Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, Cleveland, OH, USA

author-notes.corresp: ∗Corresponding author. University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, 11100 Euclid Ave, Cleveland, OH 44106, USA. Tel.: +1 440 752 0519. logan.good@uhhospitals.org

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Nontobacco nicotine dependence (NTND) is an increasing alternative to traditional tobacco use. However, limited data exist in NTND patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA). The purpose of this study was to investigate differences in complications and revision rates among patients with and without NTND undergoing THA.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The TriNetX US Collaborative Network database was queried using ICD-10 and CPT codes to identify patients aged 18 and older undergoing primary THA between 2014 and 2024. Cohorts were divided depending on history of NTND and propensity-matched based on age, gender, race, ethnicity, body mass index, and comorbidities. Rates of complications and revision THA were compared.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of 99,496,579 patients aged 18 and older were identified, of which 192,826 underwent primary THA. After exclusions, 15,561 (93.2%) were nonnicotine users and 8452 (6.8%) were NTND. After 1:1 propensity score matching, each cohort included 8378 patients. Complications including myocardial infarction, stroke, pneumonia, acute kidney injury, sepsis, emergency department visits, and rehospitalization were significantly higher at 90 days postoperatively in NTND patients (P < .05). At 1 year postoperatively, in addition to these complications, the risk of postoperative deep vein thrombosis ([OR] 1.251; P = .0369) and infection (OR 1.288; P = .045) became significantly higher. Rates of prosthetic joint infection (OR 1.485; P = .004), revision THA (OR 1.868; P = .002), and death (OR 1.575; P = .035) were significantly elevated in NTND patients compared to their counterparts at 90 days, 1 year, and 5 years postoperatively.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: NTND patients have higher rates of infection, revision, mortality, and postoperative complications including DVT, myocardial infarction, stroke, pneumonia, kidney injury, sepsis, infection, and return to the hospital. Providers should counsel NTND patients and consider screening protocols prior to operative management.

sec.title: Level of Evidence
sec.p: Retrospective cohort study, level of evidence III.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Tobacco use is a known risk factor for complications after total hip (THA) and knee arthroplasty (TKA) [[1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6], [7], [8]]. Prior studies have demonstrated increased risk for postoperative complications among cigarette smokers, including wound complications, prosthetic joint infection (PJI), and revision surgery [[3], [4], [5], [6], [7],9]. Cigarette smoking influences both innate and adaptive immune responses, invariably leading to predispositions for localized and systemic infections [10,11]. Users of smokeless tobacco have also been reported to exhibit a perioperative risk profile similar to that of smokers [8]. As a result, some authors have advocated for the cessation of tobacco products and nicotine testing before elective THA or TKA [[12], [13], [14]].

Nicotine alone has also been shown to cause extensive immune system dysregulation by inhibiting the secretion of many cytokines and altering immune cell function, negatively impacting the wound healing process [[15], [16], [17]]. Nontobacco nicotine dependence (NTND) has become an alternative to traditional tobacco use with recent studies demonstrating increased prevalence in recent years [[18], [19], [20]]. Nontobacco nicotine products may be inhaled, ingested orally, or administered transdermally. Nicotine is known to be the active ingredient of tobacco contributing to tissue hypoperfusion, epithelial dysfunction, immune dysregulation, and free radical production [[21], [22], [23]]. As a result, nontobacco nicotine use may be associated with a perioperative risk profile similar to tobacco use.

Recent studies have found NTND to be associated with higher risk for postoperative infection, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), sepsis, PJI, and revision procedure following primary TKA [24]. To our knowledge, however, no prior studies have examined the risks of nontobacco nicotine use in the setting of THA [1,4,6,8,20]. Therefore, the objective of this study was to utilize a large database to perform a propensity score-matched cohort analysis comparing the perioperative complications and rates of revision surgery between patients with NTND and those without nicotine dependence undergoing primary THA.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: The TriNetX United States Collaborative Network (Cambridge, Massachusetts) was used to perform a retrospective cohort study of aggregated and deidentified data collected from more than 118 million patients and 68 health-care organizations [25]. The platform incorporates biomedical and clinical research data from both insured and uninsured patients from a variety of organizations including hospitals, primary and specialty care centers. Access to clinical data including demographics, diagnoses, procedures, medications, laboratory values, and genomic information facilitates analysis of complex data sets [26]. Institutional review board approval was not required for this study as TriNetX follows the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act and General Data Protection Regulation guidelines for deidentification.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The United States Collaborative Network was queried on February 10, 2025, identifying all patients aged 18 and older who underwent THA between January 1, 2004, and January 1, 2024. Patients were identified using Current Procedural Terminology codes. Exclusions and patient comorbidities were determined using International Classification of Disease, 10th Revision (ICD-10) codes (Supplementary Table 1). Patients with prior history of rheumatoid arthritis, femoral acetabular impingement, post-traumatic osteoarthritis, and hip dysplasia were excluded. Patients with a history of tobacco use were also excluded. Patients were then stratified into 2 cohorts based on nicotine use: nontobacco nicotine dependence and those without a preoperative diagnosis of nicotine dependence. The NTND cohort included patients with a dependence to nicotine (ICD10:F17), while excluding patients with nicotine dependence to cigarettes (ICD10:F17.21), chewing tobacco (ICD10:F17.22), and other tobacco products (ICD10:F17.29). The control group had no documented history of nicotine dependence. Propensity score matching was performed using a greedy nearest neighbor matching algorithm with a caliper of 0.1 pooled standard deviations, accounting for variables including age, gender, race, ethnicity, body mass index, type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, liver disease, alcohol abuse, opioid abuse, anxiety and depression.

A total of 99,496,579 patients aged 18 and older were identified, of which 192,826 underwent primary THA (Fig. 1). A total of 174,071 patients remained after excluding for history of rheumatoid arthritis, femoral acetabular impingement, post-traumatic osteoarthritis, and hip dysplasia. After exclusions for tobacco use, 154,147 patients remained. The cohorts were then stratified into NTND and those without a preoperative diagnosis of nicotine dependence. Overall, 124,013 patients met the inclusion criteria. Among these, 115,561 (93.2%) were non-nicotine users and 8452 (6.8%) were NTND patients. Significant differences between the cohorts were noted for the following variables: age, gender, race, ethnicity, body mass index, type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, liver disease, alcohol abuse, opioid abuse, anxiety and depression (Table 1). After 1:1 propensity score matching, each cohort included 8378 patients. Significant differences were noted only for age (60.8 ± 11.6 vs 60.1 ± 12.8; P = .0002). Numerous medical and surgical complications were compared between cohorts at 90 days, 1 year, and 5 years postoperatively (Table 2, Table 3, Table 4).Figure 1
Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology diagram depicting the patient selection process. FAI, femoral acetabular impingement; RA, rheumatoid arthritis; OA, osteoarthritis.Table 1

sec.title: Data collection and outcomes
sec.p: THA was indicated as the index event. Patient cohorts were assessed for demographics including age, race, ethnicity, and sex. All outcomes were analyzed at 90 days and 1 year after surgery. Rates of mechanical loosening, periprosthetic hip dislocation, periprosthetic hip fracture, PJI, revision THA, and mortality were analyzed 5 years postoperatively for patients with the allotted postoperative follow-up time since primary THA. The primary outcome in this study was revision THA at 1 year. Our secondary objective was to assess the relationship between patients with NTND and the following postoperative medical and surgical complications, including DVT, pulmonary embolism, myocardial infarction (MI), stroke, pneumonia, acute kidney injury (AKI), sepsis, wound dehiscence, postoperative infection, emergency department (ED) visits, rehospitalizations, mortality, PJI, mechanical loosening, periprosthetic hip dislocation, and periprosthetic hip fracture. These outcomes were identified by ICD-10 codes (Supplementary Table 1).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The TriNetX platform was utilized for all statistical analyses using built-in statistical tools. Descriptive statistics were calculated for all continuous and categorical variables. Continuous variables were reported as mean ± standard deviation whereas categorical variables were reported as frequencies with percentages. A chi-squared (χ2) test was used to analyze categorical variables, and an independent samples t-test was used to analyze the difference in means for continuous variables. A P value ≥.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Early postoperative complications
sec.p: Postoperative complications were evaluated at 90 days and compared between NTND patients and those without a prior history of nicotine dependence. (Table 2). Overall, complications including MI (OR 1.656, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.272-2.156; P < .0001), stroke (OR 1.370, 95% CI 1.085-1.731; P = .008), pneumonia (OR 2.118, 95% CI 1.757-2.553; P < .0001), AKI (OR 1.390, 95% CI 1.190-1.624; P < .0001), sepsis (OR 1.455, 95% CI 1.142-1.855; P = .0023), PJI (OR 1.485, 95% CI 1.135-1.944; P = .004), and death (OR 1.575, 95% CI 1.030-2.409; P = .035) were significantly higher in NTND patients. NTND patients also had a significantly increased rates of ED visits (OR 1.327, 95% CI 1.185-1.486; P < .0001), rehospitalization (OR 1.490, 95% CI 1.335-1.664; P < .0001) and revision THA at 90 days (OR 1.868, 95% CI 1.244-2.804; P = .002).

sec.title: Delayed postoperative complications
sec.p: Among patients with and without NTND, delayed complications were compared between cohorts from 1 year and 5 years postoperatively (Table 3, Table 4). Notably, the rate of revision THA was significantly elevated in the NTND cohort (OR 1.466, 95% CI 1.155-1.861; P = .0015). Medical events such as DVT (OR 1.251, 95% CI 1.013-1.545; P = .0369), MI (OR 1.957, 95% CI 1.329-2.883; P = .001), stroke (OR 1.842, 95% CI 1.294-2.622; P = .001), pneumonia (OR 2.328, 95% CI 1.766-3.069; P < .0001), AKI (OR 1.336, 95% CI 1.087-1.642; P = .006), sepsis (OR 1.667, 95% CI 1.172-2.370; P = .0041), postoperative infection (OR 1.288, 95% CI 1.005-1.650; P = .045), ED visits (OR 1.374, 95% CI 1.263-1.496; P < .0001), and rehospitalization (OR 1.448, 95% CI 1.320-1.589; P < .0001) were significantly higher 1 year postoperatively in NTND patients (Table 3). Furthermore, rates of PJI (OR 1.386, 95% CI 1.101-1.745; P = .005) and death (OR 2.139, 95% CI 1.657-2.761; P < .0001) remained significantly elevated in NTND patients compared to their counterparts.

At 5 years postoperatively, rates of PJI (OR 1.409, 95% CI 1.160-1.711; P = .001), all cause revision THA (OR 1.283, 95% CI 1.069-1.540; P = .0073), and death (OR 2.118, 95% CI 1.847-2.429; P < .0001) also remained significantly higher in the NTND cohort (Table 4). However, no significant differences were appreciated between cohorts among rates of mechanical loosening (OR 0.950, 95% CI 0.609-1.482; P = .82), periprosthetic hip dislocation (OR 1.075, 95% CI 0.811-1.423; P = .616), and periprosthetic hip fracture (OR 0.988, 95% CI 0.731-1.336; P = .939).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the first study investigating the association between NTND and postoperative complications and rates of revision surgery after THA. Our results demonstrate that NTND patients are at an elevated risk for numerous postoperative complications including DVT, MI, stroke, pneumonia, AKI, sepsis, PJI, infection, ED visits, rehospitalization, and mortality up to 5 years postoperatively. Furthermore, patients with NTND also underwent revision THA at higher rates compared to those without a history of nicotine dependence.

Our NTND cohort demonstrated an increased risk for numerous infectious complications including postoperative wound infection, pneumonia, sepsis, and PJI, similar to results of other studies examining effects of traditional tobacco use in THA and TKA [3,9,27]. These results are further supported from studies in NTND patients undergoing anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, TKA, and total shoulder arthroplasty (TSA) [3,9,24,[27], [28], [29]]. Our results support that PJI and other infectious complications in NTND patients undergoing THA seem to mirror those of traditional tobacco users. In addition to immune dysregulation and postoperative infection susceptibility, nicotine is responsible for numerous other effects including tissue hypoperfusion, epithelial dysfunction, and free radical production [[21], [22], [23]]. The NTND cohort in our study demonstrated higher rates for MI and stroke at 90 days following THA. Furthermore, the risks of DVT, MI, and stroke persisted at 1 year postoperatively. In contrast to pure nicotine products, these vascular complications and systemic effects of traditional tobacco use are well known, particularly relating to complications for patients undergoing THA [[1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6], [7], [8], [9],30,31]. The results of the presents study are corroborated by prior research substantiating negative outcomes in orthopaedic patients with NTND [24,28,29]. Patients undergoing TKA have increased rates of DVT and pulmonary embolism, while patients undergoing TSA exhibited higher rates of MI and stroke [24,29]. These findings collectively highlight the need for increased preoperative strategies to mitigate the risk of NTND.

Our study is the first to analyze the relationship between NTND and mortality for patients undergoing various surgical interventions. We determined patients with NTND had increased risk for mortality at all postoperative time points compared to non-nicotine users. The 90 day mortality rates from this study were slightly higher to alternative studies in primary THA [32,33]. These results are supported by the existing body of literature investigating cigarette smokers [3,6,9,34]. Increased rates of pre-existing comorbid conditions in tobacco and nicotine users likely predispose these patients to an increase in perioperative complications and mortality thereby explaining the increased risk of medical events at 1 year following THA.

The present study also demonstrated increased risk for revision THA at 90 days, 1 year, and 5 years postoperatively among the NTND cohort. These results are relatively comparable to alternative studies investigating rates of revision in patients undergoing primary THA, with rates ranging between 0.6%-1.4% [6,35,36]. A recent study by Bongers et al demonstrated rates of revision are higher for smokers than for nonsmokers in the first 2 years following THA and TKA [37]. These results have been supported by alternative studies in total joint arthroplasty [6,7,9]. DeShazo et al also demonstrated increased rates of revision TKA in NTND patients at 3 years postoperatively, further supporting these findings [24].

In contrast to our findings, Lawand et al evaluated NTND outcomes in patients undergoing TSA, observing higher rates of mechanical loosening and prosthetic joint dislocation [29]. Although smoking has also been shown to increase risk for aseptic loosening following THA, the risk of dislocation did not correlate with smoking status which was similar to our findings in NTND patients [38]. The current study failed to demonstrate any association between NTND and aseptic loosening. Further basic science research is needed to elucidate why smoking differed from NTND in this specific instance.

Tobacco cessation is an important topic in the literature that has been shown to decrease infection rates following total joint arthroplasty [39]. Although the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons recommends tobacco smoking cessation 4-6 weeks before surgical interventions, there are no formal established national arthroplasty guidelines [40]. Recommendations remain informal likely due to inconsistent literature regarding the importance of specific preoperative cessation timelines [41, 42]. Much of the current literature suggests complete cessation approximately 4 weeks before surgery, although no established guidelines exist specifically regarding nontobacco nicotine products [13,41,42]. This highlights the need for further investigation into the appropriate preoperative cessation guideline for these patients. Given the notable morbidity and mortality risks associated with these complications, it is imperative that providers screen and provide comprehensive perioperative counseling in order to decrease complication rates. Multidisciplinary management will help optimize these patients in the perioperative setting in order to reduce complications before undergoing THA and other orthopaedic surgical interventions.

The present study is not without limitations. The retrospective design limits its objective nature and may have resulted in selection bias. Although propensity matching was successful in generating an appropriate cohort distribution, the difference in age between cohorts may have influenced our study outcomes. Although this study attempted to achieve comprehensively propensity matched cohorts, the addition of variables may have increased the risk for a type I error. This study also utilized a large, deidentified database to collect data and perform various statistical analyses. Ultimately, this led to the inability to access individual patient records and therefore subjects the accuracy of our results to appropriate ICD-10 and Current Procedural Terminology coding. In addition, variables such as differences in nicotine delivery devices and quantitative nicotine consumption are unable to be addressed. Since the study goal to isolate patients with NTND may not have been completely precise due to inaccurate coding in patient cohort generation, the inclusion and exclusion criteria in our study design is subject to these confounding variables. Despite these limitations, the benefit of utilizing a large database was that it enabled us to perform a propensity-score matched analysis and thereby mitigate the risk of selection bias, lack of randomization, and questionable generalizability inherent in other retrospective designs.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Overall, the current literature does not appropriately investigate the effects of NTND on postoperative outcomes following THA. The results of this study demonstrated that NTND is associated with an elevated rate of mortality and postoperative medical complications, including DVT, MI, stroke, pneumonia, AKI, sepsis, infection, ED visits, and rehospitalization. NTND was also associated with higher rates of PJI and revision THA compared to their counterparts up to 5 years postoperatively. The results herein serve to help surgeons counsel patients regarding postoperative risks. Further research is needed to provide further recommendations on cessation guidelines.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: The authors declare there are no conflicts of interest.
For full disclosure statements refer to doi: 10.1016/j.artd.2025.101743.
